answers.title: Outputting w different classes & Constructors
answers.body:
Here is one problem. The default Scanner delimiter is white space. Your second input for

Chocolate Strawberry 25

is Strawberry but it is trying to be parsed as an int. You need to have a consistent input format so you can properly parse the numerics.

cupcakeCS.setFlavor(inputFile.next());
cupcakeCS.setDescription("Moist chocolate cake filled with strawberry jam, topped with strawberry buttercream dipped in chocolate.");
cupcakeCS.setUnitsOnHand(inputFile.nextInt());
cupcakeCS.setPrice(2.75);

Perhaps the easiest decision is to set a specific delimiter using the Scanner.useDelimiter() method. Say the delimiter is ; your input could look like this.

Chocolate Strawberry ;25;

Notice the ; must be right before and after the number or the space will cause an exception.

answers.title: Outputting w different classes & Constructors
answers.body:
Just for fun I cooked this up.

  • It is line-based and uses /// as separator.
  • It uses 2 config files, no item config in the code.
  • Cupcake 'prototypes' and their actual 'on hand' stock size are matched by the Cupcake's name (flavor).
  • Throws a lot of Warnings when config files seem off (and yes, I put some mistakes in there on purpose).
  • Calculates in cents, to get rid of common currency problems.
  • App still crashes on NumberFormatException from the both input files. Just thought of that after posting all code here, so I'll let you fix that :-P

The Shop

package stackoverflow.cupcakemania;

import java.io.IOException;
import java.util.Map.Entry;
import java.util.TreeMap;

import stackoverflow.cupcakemania.logic.CupcakePrototype;
import stackoverflow.cupcakemania.logic.CupcakeStock;
import stackoverflow.cupcakemania.util.CupcakePrototypeManager;
import stackoverflow.cupcakemania.util.StockTransaction;

public class CupcakeShop {



    public static void main(final String... args) throws IOException {
        printCurrentStock();

        takeOut();

        putIn();

        printCurrentStock();
    }



    static private void printCurrentStock() throws IOException {
        final TreeMap<CupcakePrototype, Long> stock = CupcakeStock.getStock_sorted();
        System.out.println("Current stock:");
        for (final Entry<CupcakePrototype, Long> e : stock.entrySet()) {
            System.out.println("\t" + e.getValue() + "\t" + e.getKey());
        }
    }

    static private void takeOut() {
        final CupcakePrototype cpp = CupcakePrototypeManager.getPrototypeByName("Apple Pie Cupcake");
        final StockTransaction transaction = CupcakeStock.changeStock(cpp, -3);
        System.out.println("Take out transaction:\t" + transaction);
    }

    static private void putIn() {
        final CupcakePrototype cpp = CupcakePrototypeManager.getPrototypeByName("Black & White Cupcake");
        final StockTransaction transaction = CupcakeStock.changeStock(cpp, +20);
        System.out.println("Put in transaction:\t" + transaction);
    }



}

The Cupcake

package stackoverflow.cupcakemania.logic;

import stackoverflow.cupcakemania.util.CurrencyFormatter;

public class CupcakePrototype implements Comparable<CupcakePrototype> {



    public final String name;
    public final String description;
    public final long   priceCents;

    public CupcakePrototype(final String pName, final String pDescription, final long pPriceCents) {
        name = pName;
        description = pDescription;
        priceCents = pPriceCents;
    }



    // you CAN write getters here, but you don't have to

    public String getName() {
        return name;
    }



    /*
     * Those 2 methods are auto-generated but strongly recommended
     */
    @Override public int hashCode() {
        final int prime = 31;
        int result = 1;
        result = prime * result + ((description == null) ? 0 : description.hashCode());
        return result;
    }
    @Override public boolean equals(final Object obj) {
        if (this == obj) return true;
        if (obj == null) return false;
        if (getClass() != obj.getClass()) return false;
        final CupcakePrototype other = (CupcakePrototype) obj;
        if (description == null) {
            if (other.description != null) return false;
        } else if (!description.equals(other.description)) return false;
        return true;
    }



    /**
     * This is for alphabetical sorting, not case sensitive
     */
    @Override public int compareTo(final CupcakePrototype pO) {
        if (name == null) return -1;
        if (pO.name == null) return 1;
        return name.toLowerCase().compareTo(pO.name.toLowerCase());
    }

    @Override public String toString() {
        return name + " (" + CurrencyFormatter.format(priceCents) + ")";
    }



}

The Shop's Stock

package stackoverflow.cupcakemania.logic;

import java.io.IOException;
import java.nio.file.Files;
import java.nio.file.Path;
import java.nio.file.Paths;
import java.util.Collections;
import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.List;
import java.util.Map;
import java.util.TreeMap;

import stackoverflow.cupcakemania.util.CupcakePrototypeManager;
import stackoverflow.cupcakemania.util.StockTransaction;

public class CupcakeStock {



    static private Path getFile() {
        return Paths.get("CupcakeStock.txt");
    }

    /*
     * File format:
     *
     * name1 /// amount1
     * name2 /// amount2
     * ...
     */



    static private HashMap<CupcakePrototype, Long> sStock;

    static private void loadStock() throws IOException {
        // load prototypes to match against stock
        final Map<String, CupcakePrototype> prototypesMap = CupcakePrototypeManager.getAllPrototypes_copy();

        // load stock
        final Path file = getFile();
        final List<String> lines = Files.readAllLines(file);
        final HashMap<CupcakePrototype, Long> newStock = new HashMap<>();
        for (int i = 0; i < lines.size(); i++) {
            final String line = lines.get(i);
            if (line == null || line.trim().length() < 1) continue; // skip invalid and empty lines

            final String[] parts = line.split("///");
            if (parts == null || parts.length != 2) {
                System.out.println("WARNING: Invalid entry in file [" + file + "], line " + (i + 1) + ": Invalid amount of config parts: [" + line + "]");
                continue; // again, skip invalid entries
            }

            final String name = parts[0].trim();
            final long amount = Long.parseLong(parts[1].trim());

            final CupcakePrototype matchingPrototype = prototypesMap.get(name);
            if (matchingPrototype == null) { // no prototype found
                System.out.println("WARNING: Invalid entry in file [" + file + "], line " + (i + 1) + ": Prototype [" + name + "] not found!");
                continue; // again, skip invalid entries
            }

            // check if ccp was already registered
            if (newStock.get(matchingPrototype) != null) {
                System.out.println("WARNING: Invalid entry in file [" + file + "], line " + (i + 1) + ": Prototype [" + name + "] already registered, ignoring entry, please fix your file!");
                continue; // again, skip invalid entries

            }

            newStock.put(matchingPrototype, Long.valueOf(amount));
        }

        // check if all Prototypes were assigned a price
        for (final CupcakePrototype ccp : prototypesMap.values()) {
            final Long value = newStock.get(ccp);
            if (value == null) System.out.println("WARNING: Prototype [" + ccp.name + "] is not in stock, please refill!");
        }

        sStock = newStock;
    }



    static public Map<CupcakePrototype, Long> getStock_copy() throws IOException {
        if (sStock == null) loadStock();
        return Collections.unmodifiableMap(sStock);
    }
    static public TreeMap<CupcakePrototype, Long> getStock_sorted() throws IOException {
        if (sStock == null) loadStock();
        return new TreeMap<>(sStock);
    }
    static public Long getStockOf(final CupcakePrototype pCCP) {
        return sStock.get(pCCP);
    }

    /**
     * Adds or retrieves as many items as possible. Negative amount means take out items
     * @return null if no transaction took place
     */
    static public synchronized StockTransaction changeStock(final CupcakePrototype pCCP, final int pAmount) {
        if (pAmount == 0) return null;

        if (pAmount < 0) { // take out
            final Long stock = sStock.get(pCCP);
            if (stock == null || stock.longValue() < 1) return null;

            final long maxTransferableAmount = Math.min(-pAmount, stock.longValue());
            final long costsCents = maxTransferableAmount * pCCP.priceCents;
            final long newStockAmount = stock.longValue() - maxTransferableAmount;
            sStock.put(pCCP, Long.valueOf(newStockAmount));
            return new StockTransaction(pCCP, maxTransferableAmount, costsCents);

        } else { // put in
            final Long stock = sStock.get(pCCP);
            if (stock == null) { // did not exist before, register new value
                sStock.put(pCCP, Long.valueOf(pAmount));
            } else { // existed before, overwrite old value
                sStock.put(pCCP, Long.valueOf(pAmount + stock.longValue()));
            }
            return new StockTransaction(pCCP, pAmount, -pAmount * pCCP.priceCents);
        }
    }



}

The cupcake Manager

package stackoverflow.cupcakemania.util;

import java.io.IOException;
import java.nio.file.Files;
import java.nio.file.Path;
import java.nio.file.Paths;
import java.util.Collections;
import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.List;
import java.util.Map;

import stackoverflow.cupcakemania.logic.CupcakePrototype;

public class CupcakePrototypeManager {



    static private Path getFile() {
        return Paths.get("CupcakePrototypes.txt");
    }

    /*
     * File format:
     *
     * name1 /// price1 /// flavor1 /// description1
     * name2 /// price2 /// flavor2 /// description2
     * ...
     */


    static private HashMap<String, CupcakePrototype> sPrototypes = null;

    static private void loadAllPrototypes() throws IOException {
        final HashMap<String, CupcakePrototype> newMap = new HashMap<>();

        final Path file = getFile();
        final List<String> lines = Files.readAllLines(file);
        for (int i = 0; i < lines.size(); i++) {
            final String line = lines.get(i);
            if (line == null || line.trim().length() < 1) continue; // skip invalid and empty lines

            final String[] parts = line.split("///");
            if (parts == null || parts.length != 3) {
                System.out.println("WARNING: Invalid entry in file [" + file + "], line " + (i + 1) + ": Invalid amount of config parts: [" + line + "]");
                continue; // again, skip invalid entries
            }

            final String name = parts[0].trim();
            final long priceCents = Long.parseLong(parts[1].trim());
            final String description = parts[2].trim();
            final CupcakePrototype p = new CupcakePrototype(name, description, priceCents);
            newMap.put(name, p);
        }

        sPrototypes = newMap;
    }



    static public Map<String, CupcakePrototype> getAllPrototypes_copy() throws IOException {
        if (sPrototypes == null) loadAllPrototypes();
        return Collections.unmodifiableMap(sPrototypes);
    }
    static public CupcakePrototype getPrototypeByName(final String pName) {
        return sPrototypes.get(pName);
    }



}

Utility method

package stackoverflow.cupcakemania.util;

public class CurrencyFormatter {



    static public String format(final long pCents) {
        final long dollars = pCents / 100;
        final long cents = pCents % 100;
        final String dollarsString = dollars == 0 ? "" : (dollars + "$ ");
        final String centsString = cents == 0 ? "" : (cents + "¢ ");
        return (dollarsString + centsString).trim();
    }



}

Shop transaction

package stackoverflow.cupcakemania.util;

import stackoverflow.cupcakemania.logic.CupcakePrototype;

public class StockTransaction {

    public final CupcakePrototype   prototype;
    public final long               amountOfItemsActuallyChanged;
    public final long               generatedCostsCents;

    public StockTransaction(final CupcakePrototype pPrototype, final long pAmountOfItemsActuallyChanged, final long pGeneratedCostsCents) {
        prototype = pPrototype;
        amountOfItemsActuallyChanged = pAmountOfItemsActuallyChanged;
        generatedCostsCents = pGeneratedCostsCents;
    }

    @Override public String toString() {
        return amountOfItemsActuallyChanged + "x " + prototype.name + " (=" + CurrencyFormatter.format(generatedCostsCents) + ")";
    }

}

items.title: Improving monster spawing using ArrayList
items.body:
I'm currently working on a game for a school project where I chose to do a game similar to vampire survivors where monsters swarms the player, my problem is that whenever a monster is defeated/spawned it slows down the game bit by bit.

// handles creation of monsters
public void setMonster(int monsterCount) {
    for (int i = 0; i < monsterCount; i++) {
        try {
            gamePanel.monsterList.get(i);
        } catch (IndexOutOfBoundsException e) {
            MON_Ggob monster = new MON_Ggob(gamePanel);
            monster.entityX = gamePanel.tileSize * random.nextInt(20) + 10;
            monster.entityY = gamePanel.tileSize * random.nextInt(20) + 10;
            gamePanel.monsterList.add(monster);
        }
    }
}

// tick method for monster spawn
public void update() {
    monsterSpawnCounter++;
    if (monsterSpawnCounter > 900) {
        monsterCount += random.nextInt(10) + 1;
        monsterSpawnCounter = 0;
        gamePanel.aSetter.setMonster(monsterCount);
    }
}

private void damageEnemy(int i) {
    if (i != 999) {
        gamePanel.monsterList.get(i).life -= 1;
        if (gamePanel.monsterList.get(i).life <= 0) {
            gamePanel.monsterList.remove(i);
        }
    }
}

// checks monster collision with another monster
public int checkEntity(Entity entity, ArrayList<Entity> target) {
    int index = 999;
    for (int i = 0; i < target.size(); i++) {
        if (target.get(i) != null) {
            // get entity's solid area position
            entity.collisionArea.x = entity.entityX + entity.collisionArea.x;
            entity.collisionArea.y = entity.entityY + entity.collisionArea.y;
            // get object's solid area position
            target.get(i).collisionArea.x = target.get(i).entityX + target.get(i).collisionArea.x;
            target.get(i).collisionArea.y = target.get(i).entityY + target.get(i).collisionArea.y;
            switch (entity.entityDirection) {
                case "up":
                    entity.collisionArea.y -= entity.speed;
                    break;
                case "down":
                    entity.collisionArea.y += entity.speed;
                    break;
                case "left":
                    entity.collisionArea.x -= entity.speed;
                    break;
                case "right":
                    entity.collisionArea.x += entity.speed;
                    break;
            }
            if (entity.collisionArea.intersects(target.get(i).collisionArea)) {
                if (target.get(i) != entity) {
                    entity.collisionOn = true;
                    index = i;
                }
            }
            // reset collision area for player and items
            entity.collisionArea.x = entity.collisionAreaDefaultX;
            entity.collisionArea.y = entity.collisionAreaDefaultY;
            target.get(i).collisionArea.x = target.get(i).collisionAreaDefaultX;
            target.get(i).collisionArea.y = target.get(i).collisionAreaDefaultY;
        }
    }
    return index;
}

answers.title: How can I generate the next permutation using the Steinhaus–Johnson–Trotter algorithm?
answers.body:
The Steinhaus–Johnson–Trotter (SJT) algorithm generates permutations by performing a series of swaps based on the direction of each element. Here's an example of how you can implement the SJT algorithm in C++ to generate the next permutation:

#include <iostream>
#include <vector>
#include <algorithm>

// Function to find the largest mobile integer in a given permutation
int findLargestMobile(const std::vector<int>& perm, const std::vector<int>& dir) {
    int maxMobile = 0;
    int mobileIndex = -1;
    const int size = perm.size();
    
    for (int i = 0; i < size; ++i) {
        if (((dir[i] == -1) && (i > 0) && (perm[i] > perm[i - 1])) ||
            ((dir[i] == 1) && (i < size - 1) && (perm[i] > perm[i + 1]))) {
            if (perm[i] > maxMobile) {
                maxMobile = perm[i];
                mobileIndex = i;
            }
        }
    }
    
    return mobileIndex;
}

// Function to generate the next permutation using the Steinhaus–Johnson–Trotter algorithm
void generateNextPermutation(std::vector<int>& permutation) {
    int size = permutation.size();
    std::vector<int> direction(size, -1); // -1 represents left direction
    
    // Find the largest mobile integer
    int mobileIndex = findLargestMobile(permutation, direction);
    
    if (mobileIndex != -1) {
        int mobileElement = permutation[mobileIndex];
        int dir = direction[mobileIndex];
        
        // Swap the mobile element with the adjacent element in its direction
        std::swap(permutation[mobileIndex], permutation[mobileIndex + dir]);
        std::swap(direction[mobileIndex], direction[mobileIndex + dir]);
        
        // Reverse the direction of all elements greater than the mobile element
        for (int i = 0; i < size; ++i) {
            if (permutation[i] > mobileElement) {
                direction[i] *= -1;
            }
        }
    }
}

// Function to print a permutation
void printPermutation(const std::vector<int>& permutation) {
    for (int num : permutation) {
        std::cout << num << " ";
    }
    std::cout << std::endl;
}

int main() {
    std::vector<int> permutation = {1, 2, 3}; // Change this permutation as needed
    
    std::cout << "Current permutation: ";
    printPermutation(permutation);
    
    generateNextPermutation(permutation);
    
    std::cout << "Next permutation: ";
    printPermutation(permutation);
    
    return 0;
}

Answer:

Current permutation: 4 2 1 3 
Next permutation: 4 2 3 1

Reason:

The Steinhaus–Johnson–Trotter algorithm follows this structure: the sequence of permutations it generates consists of (n-1)! blocks of permutations, so that within each block the permutations agree on the ordering of the numbers from 1 to n-1 and differ only in the position of n. The blocks themselves are ordered recursively, according to the Steinhaus–Johnson–Trotter algorithm for one less element.

the positions in which n is placed occur either in descending or ascending order, and the blocks alternate between these two orders: the placements of n in the first block are in descending order, in the second block they are in ascending order, in the third block they are in descending order, and so on.

Thus, from the single permutation on one element,

1

one may place the number 2 in each possible position in descending order to form a list of two permutations on two elements,

1 2
2 1

Then, one may place the number 3 in each of three different positions for these two permutations, in descending order for the first permutation 1 2, and then in ascending order for the permutation 2 1:

1 2 3
1 3 2
3 1 2
3 2 1
2 3 1
2 1 3

To learn more check:

  1. Steinhaus–Johnson–Trotter algorithm
  2. Comparative Study on the Performance of Permutation Algorithms

Time Complexity: The time complexity of generating the next permutation using the Steinhaus–Johnson–Trotter algorithm is O(n), where n is the length of the input sequence to permute 12. The algorithm generates all permutations of a sequence by swapping just two adjacent elements of the sequence. Therefore, to generate the next permutation, we only need to swap two adjacent elements in the sequence.

Here what your looking for:

4213
4231
4321
3421
3412
3142
1342
1324
1234
2134
2143
2413 
/* 2413 This is what you expected but you won't find the result using next permutation algorithm go for all permutation using SJT*/

To find all permutation -> Find all permutation using SJT

I hope this helps!

answers.body_markdown: Upon further inspection, it is not possible to generate the next permutation i+1 given a permutation i. This is because the program has no way of knowing what the directions of the permutation i numbers are by itself.

items.title: How can I generate the next permutation using the Steinhaus–Johnson–Trotter algorithm?
items.body:
How can I take a permutation i and generate the (i+1)th permutation with the Steinhaus-Johnson-Trotter (SJT) algorithm? There are solutions to generate all of the permutations using the SJT algorithm, but since the permutations follow a pattern, I want to generate the next permutation.

I attempted to write such an algorithm. However, for the permutation 4213, the next permutation is supposed to be 2413, but this program gives the previous permutation 4231 instead. How I can generate the next permutation i+1, given i?


public class SJTAlgorithm {


    private int[] dir;

    // Constructor to initialize the directions
    public SJTAlgorithm(int n) {
        dir = new int[n];
        // Initially, all directions are set to -1 (left).
        for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
            dir[i] = -1;
        }
    }
    // Function to check if an integer is mobile
    private static boolean isMobile(int[] permutation, int[] dir, int index) {
        int nextIndex = index + dir[index];
        // An integer is mobile if the next index is within bounds and
        // the adjacent integer in the direction it's moving is smaller.
        return nextIndex >= 0 && nextIndex < permutation.length && permutation[index] > permutation[nextIndex];
    }

    // Function to find the largest mobile integer
    private static int getMobileIndex(int[] permutation, int[] dir) {
        int mobilePrev = 0, mobileIndex = -1;
        for (int i = 0; i < permutation.length; i++) {
            if (isMobile(permutation, dir, i) && permutation[i] > mobilePrev) {
                mobilePrev = permutation[i];
                mobileIndex = i;
            }
        }
        return mobileIndex;
    }

    // Function to find the next permutation
    public static int[] nextPermutation(int[] permutation) {
        int n = permutation.length;
        int[] dir = new int[n];

        // Initially, all directions are set to -1 (left).
        for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
            dir[i] = -1;
        }

        // Find the largest mobile integer in the permutation.
        int mobileIndex = getMobileIndex(permutation, dir);
        if (mobileIndex == -1) { // No mobile integer means this is the last permutation.
            return null;
        }

        // Swap the mobile integer with the adjacent integer in its current direction.
        int swapIndex = mobileIndex + dir[mobileIndex];
        int temp = permutation[mobileIndex];
        permutation[mobileIndex] = permutation[swapIndex];
        permutation[swapIndex] = temp;

        // Change the direction of all integers larger than the current mobile integer.
        for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) {
            if (permutation[i] > permutation[swapIndex]) {
                dir[i] = -dir[i];
            }
        }

        return permutation;
    }

    // Main function to test the algorithm
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        int[] permutation = {4, 2, 1, 3};
        SJTAlgorithm sjt = new SJTAlgorithm(permutation.length); // Initialize the SJTAlgorithm instance
        int[] nextPerm = sjt.nextPermutation(permutation);

        if (nextPerm != null) {
            System.out.println("Next permutation:");
            for (int num : nextPerm) {
                System.out.print(num + " ");
            }
        } else {
            System.out.println("No next permutation available (last permutation reached).");
        }
    }
}

[![enter image description here][1]][1]

  [1]: https://i.stack.imgur.com/TajXb.jpg

answers.body_markdown:
You have an AuthenticationException which is a runtime exception. Read about it here [Spring Security Authentication][1].
The default configuration of WebSecurity, as said here [HttpSecurity][2] is:

    protected void configure(HttpSecurity http) throws Exception {
    http
        .authorizeRequests()
            .anyRequest().authenticated()
            .and()
        .formLogin()
            .and()
        .httpBasic();
    }
Try to add `.anyRequest().authenticated()` to your code.


  [1]: https://spring.io/guides/topicals/spring-security-architecture/#_authentication
  [2]: https://docs.spring.io/spring-security/site/docs/current/reference/html/jc.html#jc-httpsecurity
answers.title: Spring security works with GET but not with other methods

You have an AuthenticationException which is a runtime exception. Read about it here Spring Security Authentication. The default configuration of WebSecurity, as said here HttpSecurity is:

protected void configure(HttpSecurity http) throws Exception {
http
    .authorizeRequests()
        .anyRequest().authenticated()
        .and()
    .formLogin()
        .and()
    .httpBasic();
}

Try to add .anyRequest().authenticated() to your code.

A KStream can consume multiple topics at once, but a KTable doesn't store data by a topic name. You'd need to filter per topic name, such as with `branch` operator or TopicNameExtractor, or just create 3 unique KStream instances, then create unique statestores with `toTable`

KTables automatically store values with latest keys

answers.title: Butterfly pattern output
answers.body:
You're missing spaces, replace the 2* by 4*

You can also have a lighter code using String.repeat

public static void pattern(int n) {
    String stars;
    for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
        stars = "* ".repeat(i);
        System.out.println(stars + " ".repeat(4 * (n - i)) + stars);
    }
    for (int i = n; i >= 1; i--) {
        stars = "* ".repeat(i);
        System.out.println(stars + " ".repeat(4 * (n - i)) + stars);
    }
}

answers.title: Butterfly pattern output
answers.body:
Here is an example.

String create(int n, char c) {
    StringBuilder a = new StringBuilder(), b;
    String s = String.valueOf(c), d = System.lineSeparator();
    int i;
    for (i = 1; i <= n; i++) {
        b = new StringBuilder();
        b.append(s.repeat(i * 2));
        b.insert(i, " ".repeat((n - i) * 2));
        b.append(d);
        a.append(b);
    }
    for (i = n - 1; i >= 1; i--) {
        b = new StringBuilder();
        b.append(s.repeat(i * 2));
        b.insert(i, " ".repeat((n - i) * 2));
        b.append(d);
        a.append(b);
    }
    return a.toString();
}

public class butterflypattern {
    
    public static void Pattern(int n){
        for(int i=1; i<=n; i++){
            for(int j=1; j<=i; j++){
                System.out.print("* ");
            }
            for(int j=1; j<=2*(n-i); j++){
                System.out.print(" ");
            }
            for(int j=1; j<=i; j++){
                System.out.print("* ");
            }
            System.out.println();
        }
        for(int i=n; i>=1; i--){
            for(int j=1; j<=i; j++){
                System.out.print("* ");
            }
            for(int j=1; j<=2*(n-i); j++){
                System.out.print(" ");
            }
            for(int j=1; j<=i; j++){
                System.out.print("* ");
            }

answers.body_markdown:
Impossible to answer without a LOT of specifics. Often the Threat.sleep(1000) command is the simplest solution to the problem. 

It's important to always remember the reasoning behind the tests. It's not always essential for Selenium tests to run at the speed of light. It's generally fairly acceptable for these kinds of test to run slower, so personally I wouldn't really worry too much about this stuff if it's still running at an acceptable pace. 

A lot of these challenges come from the way the UIs have been designed and built. Adding in the waits often are the only viable solution to have as a buffer for the services behind the scenes you are working with. 

Unfortunately not a 100% reliable solution for any situation, just the nature of how everything plugs together under the hood.

answers.title: how to run a war file in maven application?
answers.body:
below Command is not correct to run.

java -jar azure-b2c-oauth2.war

This only works for jar based packaging, If you choose to package your application as a war file you should refer to your server and IDE documentation.

Refer : http://docs.spring.io/spring-boot/docs/current/reference/html/using-boot-running-your-application.html

refer for server deployment: https://www.mkyong.com/spring-boot/spring-boot-deploy-war-file-to-tomcat/

OR

you can build package spring boot as jar using below ,

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<project xmlns="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0" 
xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
    xsi:schemaLocation="http://maven.apache.org/POM/4.0.0 http://maven.apache.org/xsd/maven-4.0.0.xsd">
<!-- ... -->
<packaging>jar</packaging>
<!-- ... -->
</project>

and then use java -jar azure-b2c-oauth2.jar

answers.title: Removing print statement affects functionality... corruption at play?
answers.body:
As to the actual cause of your problem - I can't say (with accuracy) as it caused to many side effects and issues - not unsurprising when using Robot this way.

However, I would:

  • Release the mouse button first, as the window may been dragged
  • Make use of Robot#delay to inject a small delay between the events to allow time for the systems to process them (otherwise it may choose to ignore some as they coming to fast)

However, I was able to replicate the functionality using a ComponentListener instead...

import java.awt.EventQueue;
import java.awt.GraphicsConfiguration;
import java.awt.GridBagLayout;
import java.awt.Insets;
import java.awt.Rectangle;
import java.awt.Toolkit;
import java.awt.event.ComponentAdapter;
import java.awt.event.ComponentEvent;
import java.awt.event.WindowEvent;
import java.awt.event.WindowStateListener;
import javax.swing.JFrame;
import javax.swing.JLabel;
import javax.swing.JPanel;
import javax.swing.border.EmptyBorder;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        new Main();
    }

    public Main() {
        EventQueue.invokeLater(new Runnable() {
            @Override
            public void run() {
                JFrame frame = new JFrame();
                frame.add(new TestPane());
                frame.pack();
                frame.setLocationRelativeTo(null);
                frame.setVisible(true);
                frame.addComponentListener(new ComponentAdapter() {
                    @Override
                    public void componentMoved(ComponentEvent e) {
                        GraphicsConfiguration gc = e.getComponent().getGraphicsConfiguration();
                        Insets insets = Toolkit.getDefaultToolkit().getScreenInsets(gc);
                        Rectangle bounds = gc.getBounds();
                        int height = bounds.height - (insets.top + insets.bottom);
                        int range = height - (e.getComponent().getHeight() * 2);

                        if (e.getComponent().getY() > range) {
                            frame.setExtendedState(JFrame.ICONIFIED);
                        }
                    }
                });

                frame.addWindowStateListener(new WindowStateListener() {
                    @Override
                    public void windowStateChanged(WindowEvent e) {
                        if (e.getNewState() == JFrame.ICONIFIED) {
                            frame.setLocationRelativeTo(null);
                        }
                    }

                });
            }
        });
    }

    public class TestPane extends JPanel {
        public TestPane() {
            setBorder(new EmptyBorder(32, 32, 32, 32));
            setLayout(new GridBagLayout());
            add(new JLabel("Nothing to see here"));
        }
    }
}

Essentially what this does is, on move, it will calculate the current screens viewable size (taking into account the menu and task bar), calculate a "hit zone" which is the height of the screen minus double the window height, when the window passes this "hit zone" it will be minimised.

As an additional feature, when the window is minimised, it's location will be reset (to the center of the screen)

As a nice side effect, this is now cross platform capable

items.title: Removing print statement affects functionality... corruption at play?
items.body:
I wrote a java program which will minimize a window when moved to lower portion of screen. It performs the task by moving the mouse with Robot to the minimize button and pressing it with mousePress and mouseRelease. I'm certain there is a more ideal way to write this program but I am not looking for that.

I noticed something strange when testing it. When removing a print statement, the program did not work as expected, and did not minimize the window. The print statement should have no effect on the functionality of the program, so I think there may be some sort of corruption at play. Does the Point variable not actualize without the print statement for some reason?

I am wondering what is causing this failure and seeking an explanation as to what is going on behind the scenes with this issue.

Here is the code:

import java.awt.AWTException;
import java.awt.Point;
import java.awt.Robot;
import java.awt.event.InputEvent;

import javax.swing.JFrame;

public class AutoMinimize {

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        JFrame frame = new JFrame("My mini frame");
        frame.setSize(200,200);
        frame.setResizable(false);
        frame.setDefaultCloseOperation(JFrame.EXIT_ON_CLOSE);
        frame.setLocationRelativeTo(null);
        
        frame.setVisible(true);
        
        outerloop:
        while(true) {
            Point location = frame.getLocation();
            System.out.println(location); //Comment out this print statement and it doesnt work??
            if (location.getY()>700) {
                try {
                    Thread.sleep(1000);
                    location = frame.getLocation();
                    Robot r = new Robot();
                    r.mouseMove(((int) location.getX()+34), ((int) location.getY()+14));
                    r.mousePress(InputEvent.BUTTON1_MASK);
                    r.mouseRelease(InputEvent.BUTTON1_MASK);
                    break outerloop;
                } catch (AWTException e) {
                    // TODO Auto-generated catch block
                    e.printStackTrace();
                } catch (InterruptedException e) {
                    // TODO Auto-generated catch block
                    e.printStackTrace();
                }
            }
        }
    }
}

NOTE: the mouse movement works for MacOS systems, but you may need to adjust coordinates for different operating systems.

answers.body_markdown:
The easiest way to achieve this since Kotlin 1.1 is the [class reference syntax](https://kotlinlang.org/docs/reference/reflection.html#bound-class-references-since-11):

    something::class

If you use Kotlin 1.0, you can convert the obtained Java class to a KClass instance by calling the `.kotlin` extension property:

    something.javaClass.kotlin
answers.title: Kotlin: Equivalent of getClass() for KClass
answers.body:
The easiest way to achieve this since Kotlin 1.1 is the class reference syntax:

something::class

If you use Kotlin 1.0, you can convert the obtained Java class to a KClass instance by calling the .kotlin extension property:

something.javaClass.kotlin

answers.body_markdown:
*EDIT: See comments, below, and answer from Alexander, above. This advice was originally for Kotlin 1.0 and it seems is now obsolete.*

Since the language doesn't support a direct way to get this yet, [consider defining an extension method for now][1].

    fun<T: Any> T.getClass(): KClass<T> {
        return javaClass.kotlin
    }

    val test = 0
    println("Kotlin type: ${test.getClass()}")

Or, if you prefer a property:

    val<T: Any> T.kClass: KClass<T>
        get() = javaClass.kotlin

    val test = 0
    println("Kotlin type: ${test.kClass}")


  [1]: https://kotlinlang.org/docs/reference/extensions.html

}

println("Kotlin type: ${test.getClass()}")

Or, if you prefer a property:

With javaClass.simpleName you can obtain your class name. Also the above example is very useful for android developers to declare on top of the class as an instance variable for logging purposes.

answers.title: Kotlin: Equivalent of getClass() for KClass
answers.body:
Here are different Implementations to get class names. You can utilize it as per your requirements.

import kotlin.reflect.KClass

val <T : Any > T.kClassName: KClass<out T>
get() {
    return javaClass.kotlin
}

Here we can get the class name in kotlin

val <T : Any > T.classNameKotlin: String?
get() {
    return javaClass.kotlin.simpleName
}

Here we can get the class name in kotlin

val <T : Any > T.classNameJava: String
get() {
    return javaClass.simpleName
}

Here are the outputs to the following operations.

fun main(){

val userAge = 0

println(userAge.kClassName) 
Output: class java.lang.Integer (Kotlin reflection is not available)

println(userAge.classNameKotlin)
Output: Int

println(userAge.classNameJava)
Output: Integer
}

answers.title: Kotlin: Equivalent of getClass() for KClass
answers.body:
Since Kotlin 1.5.21 (org.jetbrains.kotlin:kotlin-stdlib:1.5.21)

val TAG = javaClass.simpleName will work no more!

Error "Not enough information to infer type variable T"

/**
 * Returns the runtime Java class of this object.
 */
public inline val <T : Any> T.javaClass: Class<T>
    @Suppress("UsePropertyAccessSyntax")
    get() = (this as java.lang.Object).getClass() as Class<T>

@Deprecated("Use 'java' property to get Java class corresponding to this Kotlin class or cast this instance to Any if you really want to get the runtime Java class of this implementation of KClass.", ReplaceWith("(this as Any).javaClass"), level = DeprecationLevel.ERROR)
public inline val <T : Any> KClass<T>.javaClass: Class<KClass<T>>
    @JvmName("getRuntimeClassOfKClassInstance")
    @Suppress("UsePropertyAccessSyntax")
    get() = (this as java.lang.Object).getClass() as Class<KClass<T>>

You can try now YourClassName::class.java.simpleName

answers.title: Kotlin: Equivalent of getClass() for KClass
answers.body:
I think this is the better solution. Found here https://www.techiedelight.com/determine-class-name-in-kotlin/

fun main() {
    val s = "Kotlin"
    println(s::class)                           // class kotlin.String
    println(s::class.qualifiedName)             // kotlin.String
    println(s::class.simpleName)                // String
}

<configuration>

to the springdoc-openapi-maven-plugin <plugin> section

Source: The plugin's documentation (https://github.com/springdoc/springdoc-openapi-maven-plugin)

comments.body_markdown: I don't know how this interacts with ClassPathResource and spring. In vanilla java, the _right_ way to do this stuff is `SomeClass.class.getResource`. __not__ `getClass()` (because that breaks when you subclass), __not__ `SomeClass.class.getClassLoader()` (it's pointless code, and dangerous: In exotic situations, that's `null` and causes an NPE). This ensures the loader used is the one that has loaded `SomeClass.class`. Which you know and control, so you can be certain the resource WILL be found then.

This ensures the loader used is the one that has loaded SomeClass.class. Which you know and control, so you can be certain the resource WILL be found then.

items.body_markdown:
I've got a random ClassLoader issue in production.

Scheduled jobs use Thymeleaf templates to send emails. Sometimes (every 2 to 3 days), template is not found because underlying ClassPathResource is not found (while other tasks running at the same time find the same template).

After adding some traces, I found that when the problem occurs, the current thread's ClassLoader is not the same as usual:

 - `org.springframework.boot.loader.LaunchedURLClassLoader`: resource
   found, OK
 - `jdk.internal.loader.ClassLoaders$AppClassLoader`: resource **not** found, problem occurs

Here is the output of getting the classloader on the Spring singleton bean providing the async mail sending method, in the catch block where the problem occurs:

    getClass().getClassLoader(): org.springframework.boot.loader.LaunchedURLClassLoader@17a7cec2
    currentThread().getContextClassLoader(): jdk.internal.loader.ClassLoaders$AppClassLoader@5cb0d902
    ClassUtils.getDefaultClassLoader(): jdk.internal.loader.ClassLoaders$AppClassLoader@5cb0d902
    ClassPathResource.getClassLoader(): jdk.internal.loader.ClassLoaders$AppClassLoader@5cb0d902

The question was: why someday the classloader is not Spring's LaunchedURLClassLoader anymore, but switches to JDK internal's AppClassLoader?

**Then how can we ensure that the same ClassLoader (here LaunchedURLClassLoader) will always be used, even on new threads created by ThreadPoolExecutor? Using Spring config?**

In my case, it occurs on `@Retryable @Async` methods launched by `@Scheduled` tasks.

If anyone got the same kind of issue, I'd be glad to hear how you dealth with it.

An obvious workaround is to add retry logic, but I want to fix the issue so that ClassLoader does not change.

I was not able to reproduce the issue when running existing code.

Problem occurs with OpenJDK 17, Spring Boot 2.7.17 (Spring Framework 5.3.30).

Using Spring Boot defaults, `@EnableScheduling` and `@EnableAsync` and `@EnableRetry`

---

EDIT: found [JDK-8184335][1] but it relates to ForkJoinPool and I'm using the default ThreadPoolExecutor. Same for below:

[SO: CompletableFuture / ForkJoinPool Set Class Loader][2]

[Spring Boot: Java 11 and ForkJoinPool.commonPool() class loading issue #15737][3]

[Spring Boot: Asynchronous deserialization performed by Hazelcast may fail due to the wrong ClassLoader being used #24836][4]


  [1]: https://bugs.openjdk.org/browse/JDK-8184335
  [2]: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49113207/completablefuture-forkjoinpool-set-class-loader
  [3]: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/issues/15737
  [4]: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-boot/issues/24836
items.title: ClassLoader changes randomly
items.body:
I've got a random ClassLoader issue in production.

Scheduled jobs use Thymeleaf templates to send emails. Sometimes (every 2 to 3 days), template is not found because underlying ClassPathResource is not found (while other tasks running at the same time find the same template).

After adding some traces, I found that when the problem occurs, the current thread's ClassLoader is not the same as usual:

  • org.springframework.boot.loader.LaunchedURLClassLoader: resource found, OK
  • jdk.internal.loader.ClassLoaders$AppClassLoader: resource not found, problem occurs

Here is the output of getting the classloader on the Spring singleton bean providing the async mail sending method, in the catch block where the problem occurs:

getClass().getClassLoader(): org.springframework.boot.loader.LaunchedURLClassLoader@17a7cec2
currentThread().getContextClassLoader(): jdk.internal.loader.ClassLoaders$AppClassLoader@5cb0d902
ClassUtils.getDefaultClassLoader(): jdk.internal.loader.ClassLoaders$AppClassLoader@5cb0d902
ClassPathResource.getClassLoader(): jdk.internal.loader.ClassLoaders$AppClassLoader@5cb0d902

The question was: why someday the classloader is not Spring's LaunchedURLClassLoader anymore, but switches to JDK internal's AppClassLoader?

Then how can we ensure that the same ClassLoader (here LaunchedURLClassLoader) will always be used, even on new threads created by ThreadPoolExecutor? Using Spring config?

In my case, it occurs on @Retryable @Async methods launched by @Scheduled tasks.

If anyone got the same kind of issue, I'd be glad to hear how you dealth with it.

An obvious workaround is to add retry logic, but I want to fix the issue so that ClassLoader does not change.

I was not able to reproduce the issue when running existing code.

Problem occurs with OpenJDK 17, Spring Boot 2.7.17 (Spring Framework 5.3.30).

Using Spring Boot defaults, @EnableScheduling and @EnableAsync and @EnableRetry

EDIT: found JDK-8184335 but it relates to ForkJoinPool and I'm using the default ThreadPoolExecutor. Same for below:

SO: CompletableFuture / ForkJoinPool Set Class Loader

Spring Boot: Java 11 and ForkJoinPool.commonPool() class loading issue #15737

Spring Boot: Asynchronous deserialization performed by Hazelcast may fail due to the wrong ClassLoader being used #24836

Here are some relevant _Wikipedia_ articles, _[Stack-based memory allocation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stack-based_memory_allocation)_, and _[Memory management](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_management#Manual_memory_management)_.

comments.body_markdown: the constructor is calling itself again and again -> each cal a new *frame* is created on the stack and not released, not just an object on the heap -> since the stack is smaller than the heap, the stack overflows first

comments.body_markdown: If heap is full you get an OutOfMemoryError; if the stack is full, you get an StackOverflowError.

answers.title: com.mysql.jdbc.exceptions.jdbc4.MySQLIntegrityConstraintViolationException: Column 'hourId' cannot be null
answers.body:
The error says that hourId has got a NULL value, so you must avoid it. For exemple, you could use:

String hourId = request.getParameter("hourId");
if (hourId==null)
    hourId="";

As long as the column accepts an empty string. If not, you must change the table definition to allow nulls:

 ALTER TABLE tblstaffallocation
   MODIFY COLUMN hourId INTEGER NULL;

answers.title: com.mysql.jdbc.exceptions.jdbc4.MySQLIntegrityConstraintViolationException: Column 'hourId' cannot be null
answers.body:
This is good practice to have primary key per table and key property of the primary key is not allowing null values... ORM/Hibernate strictly follows this principle where each entity/persistent bean should have primary key.. Answer to your question is you are trying to insert null value to a primary\non nullable column .... so you are getting the exception... Below code is not good practice. If you intentionally made your column nullable then obviously no point trying to insert null/empty value.. Its better to design your data model before actually starting implementing the application. 

if (hourId==null)
    hourId="";

Hope this will be helpful...

Cheers!

answers.title: Understand OutOfMemoryError: Required array length error
answers.body: Yes, I think it means exactly that. It tries to allocate 2,627,438,736 elements and that is way more that the maximum allowed 2,147,483,647 in Java array.

answers.body_markdown:
The error message `java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Required array length 1313719368 + 1313719368 is too large` suggests that your Java program is attempting to create an array with a size that exceeds the maximum allowed array size in Java.

In Java, the maximum size of an array is constrained by the maximum positive integer value, which is Integer.MAX_VALUE or 2^31 - 1 (approximately 2.147 billion elements). It appears that your program is trying to create an array whose size is larger than what Java can handle.

The error message indicates an attempt to create an array whose length is the sum of two very large numbers, 1313719368 and 1313719368, which exceeds the maximum array size allowed in Java.


You can resolve the issue by 
- Increase JVM Heap Size: you can try increasing the Java Virtual Machine (JVM) heap size, but keep in mind the system's available memory.
- Stream Processing: Not all data at a time but get data in chunks if possible.

answers.title: Understand OutOfMemoryError: Required array length error
answers.body:
This OutOfMemoryError is being thrown by the internal JDK class jdk.internal.util.ArraysSupport.

    private static int hugeLength(int oldLength, int minGrowth) {
        int minLength = oldLength + minGrowth;
        if (minLength < 0) { // overflow
            throw new OutOfMemoryError(
                "Required array length " + oldLength + " + " + minGrowth + " is too large");
        } else if (minLength <= SOFT_MAX_ARRAY_LENGTH) {
            return SOFT_MAX_ARRAY_LENGTH;
        } else {
            return minLength;
        }
    }

This method is called by the public JDK-internal method ArraysSupport.newLength, which explains its purpose and this exception behavior in its Javadoc comment:

Computes a new array length given an array's current length, a minimum growth amount, and a preferred growth amount. The computation is done in an overflow-safe fashion.

This method is used by objects that contain an array that might need to be grown in order to fulfill some immediate need (the minimum growth amount) but would also like to request more space (the preferred growth amount) in order to accommodate potential future needs.

[…]

If the minimum required length exceeds Integer.MAX_VALUE, then this method throws OutOfMemoryError.

A search in my IDE against the Java 21 library finds a number of different locations in the JDK that call ArraysSupport.newLength, including ArrayList, FileInputStream, and AbstractStringBuilder. In your case, the stack trace tells us that this is happening within ArrayList.addAll by its internal private method ArrayList.grow.

What this tells me is that the third-party program is performing some operation that results in the ArrayList class needing to allocate an array larger than the maximum array length supported by Java. The rest of the stack trace would likely show what part of the third-party triggered the JDK call that resulted in the error.

To answer your question about whether it "tries to allocate 2,627,438,736 elements" and fails due to exceeding the maximum array length, that's close to what's happening here. To be more precise, the code checks whether an array of the given summed length is legal to create, or whether would exceed the maximum legal array length (Integer.MAX_VALUE). If the array length would be too long, it fails rather than attempting to create an array of the invalid length. In particular, the third party code is attempting to add items to an ArrayList that would increase its size past Integer.MAX_VALUE.

answers.title: How can I check duplicated words within an Array and count them?
answers.body:
Since you are only entering three words, you don't really need an array or any loops for this.

  • read each word into three variables.

  • Compare word1 to word2.

  • if equal, assign one to sameWord and increment the count

  • compare word3 to sameWord, if equal, they must all be equal since sameWord would only be set to a word if the previous conditional succeeded.

  • else compare word3 to word1 and word2, if either are equal, then there are two matches so increment the count. Remember, the previous count was not incremented.

  • then just print the results.


Scanner scan = new Scanner(System.in);
int sameCount = 1;
String sameWord = "@";
String word1 = scan.next().toLowerCase();
String word2 = scan.next().toLowerCase();
String word3 = scan.next().toLowerCase();
if (word1.equals(word2)) {
    sameCount++;
    sameWord = word1;

}
if (word3.equals(sameWord)) {
    sameCount++;
} else if (word3.equals(word1) || word3.equals(word2)) {
    sameWord = word3;
    sameCount++;
}

if (sameCount > 1) {
    System.out.printf("%d words were the same.%n", sameCount);
    System.out.printf("The word was '%s'%n", sameWord);
} else {
    System.out.println("None of the words were the same");
}

answers.body_markdown:
You can rely on using the `register(...)` method each time without keeping a reference in your code since it is guaranteed to only create one counter for the same combination of name and tags.

However, be careful if your tags has a very large unique combinations since this will be added to a map in the micrometer library.

From the javadocs:

> Add the counter to a single registry, or return an existing counter in that registry. The returned counter will be unique for each registry, but each registry is guaranteed to only create one counter for the same combination of name and tags.

[Reference][1]


  [1]: https://javadoc.io/static/io.micrometer/micrometer-core/1.12.0/io/micrometer/core/instrument/Counter.Builder.html#register(io.micrometer.core.instrument.MeterRegistry)

answers.title: Error "Name for argument of type [java.util.UUID] not specified, and parameter name information not found in class file either"with spring 3.2 upgrade
answers.body:
Any idea what is going on?

Some meta-tool (such as an annotation processor; something that either directly inspects class files, or uses reflection to attempt to glean info from your classes based not on implementing methods in interfaces and classes, but on structure alone - such as 'any method that starts with the letters get') requires the names of parameters to do its job.

However, java-the-language is set up so that param names are irrelevant, and as a consequence, in basic java (as in, compiling without any flags for old versions of java), they were not included whatsoever in your class files - if you write:

public void foo(String x, int y) {}

Then what ends up in the class file is:

  • public, yes, as a flag.
  • The identity string foo(Ljava/lang/String;I)V.
  • That string contains void (V), and both param types (String, and I is for int), and of course the method name. But not x or y.

Because param names come in handy for all sorts of things, these days java compilers tend to include that information by default. But the basic language design does not need them to exist (as an example, in java, it is not possible to e.g. call that as foo(x: "Hi", y: 5) - in many languages you can do that, in java, you cannot.

For whatever reason, class files you have obtained no longer include this information.

There are a few explanations:

  • compile, passing -g:vars to javac. You may have to investigate how to tell your build tool to do this. This tells the build tool to include debug symbols for variable names. This includes method param names. This works on every javac, but, you should probably instead use...
  • The -parameters option which is new, and a better way to do this.

if you're using maven, looks something like:

<groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
<artifactId>maven-compiler-plugin</artifactId>
...
<configuration>
  <release>21</release>
  <compilerArgs>
    <arg>-parameters</arg>
  </compilerArgs>
</configuration>

Exactly which class file is missing method param names - that's not clear from your paste, unfortunately.

You can check whether they have it using reflection:

System.out.println(
  String.class.getMethod("charAt", int.class).getParameters()[0].getName()
);

This prints 'arg0', which is what .getName() ends up doing when this information is not present. So, my JDK doesn't have them in the core libs.

A second way to figure this out is with javap, the decompiler. It shows arg names - if it shows arg0, arg1, and so forth, it's not included. If it shows an actual name, it is, and that meta tool that is throwing those errors can process those files.

items.title: Error "Name for argument of type [java.util.UUID] not specified, and parameter name information not found in class file either"with spring 3.2 upgrade
items.body:
After upgrading my code from Java 17 and Spring-boot 3.1.3 to Java 21 and String-boot 3.2.0, I've started to see errors like the ones below, when calling the REST APIs:

UPDATE: After running some more tests, using different spring-boot versions with Java 21, I can tell that the problem is only visible with spring-boot 3.2.0.
The system works fine if I use spring-boot 3.1.6 with Java 21.

Name for argument of type [java.util.UUID] not specified, and parameter name information not found in class file either.

Name for argument of type [java.lang.String] not specified, and parameter name information not found in class file either.

Name for argument of type [java.lang.Integer] not specified, and parameter name information not found in class file either.

Any idea what is going on? Is there a spring-boot glitch as it seem to have had occurred in the past? https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-loaded/issues/68

Thanks

PS: the code was working ok before doing this upgrade. Nothing else changed but the Java version and the Spring version.

answers.title: Is it wrong to use "try catch" inside a reactive stream operator(project reactor)?
answers.body:
In Reactive Streams when an error is signaled, the publisher is considered terminated:

Terminal State: For a Publisher: When onComplete or onError has been signalled. For a Subscriber: When an onComplete or onError has been received.

In order to prevent the termination of the Publisher in Reactor, you can try/catch or use onErrorContinue depending on your requirements.

In my opinion there is nothing wrong with try/catch and sometimes like in the following scenario, it's the best solution, because onErrorContinue will skip all error events, and sometimes you will handle terminal and non-terminal exceptions in the same chain of operators, for example:

        Flux.just(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7)
            .map(item -> {
                System.out.println("item = " + item);
                if (item.equals(5)) {
                    throw new IllegalArgumentException("Terminal event"); // terminal exception
                }
                return item;
            })
            .mapNotNull(item -> {
                System.out.println("item = " + item);
                if (item.equals(3))  {
                    throw new IllegalArgumentException("Non-terminal event"); // non-terminal exception
                }
                return item;
            })
            .onErrorContinue((error, item) -> {
                System.out.println(error.getMessage());
            }).subscribe(item -> System.out.println("got element :" + item));

In this scenario, both exceptions thrown are the same type, but one is considered a terminal event. The correct solution for this problem in my opinion is using try/catch inside flatMap instead of onErrorContinue:

        Flux.just(1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7)
            .map(item -> {
                System.out.println("item = " + item);
                if (item.equals(5)) {
                    throw new IllegalArgumentException("Terminal event"); // terminal exception
                }
                return item;
            })
            .flatMap(item -> {
                System.out.println("item = " + item);
                try {
                    if (item.equals(3))  {
                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("Non-terminal event"); // non-terminal exception
                    }
                    return Flux.just(item);
                } catch (IllegalArgumentException e) {
                    return Flux.empty();
                }
            })
            .subscribe(item -> System.out.println("got element :" + item));

This way the terminal event will end the Publisher, and the non-terminal event will be processed, emmiting Flux.empty() in case of exception.

items.body_markdown:
I was exploring reactive streams with project reactor, and I had a use case where I needed to skip to the next event if an error occurred during the processing of the current event (e.g., deserialization error).

For such a use case, I found out that I can use the `onErrorContinue` operator, but I also thought about wrapping my callback with a `try catch` like this:

```
Flux.just(1, 2, 3, 4, 5).mapNotNull(item -> {                                                         
    try {                                                                                             
        System.out.println("item = " + item);                                                         
        if (item.equals(3)) throw new IllegalArgumentException(); // deserialization issue for example
        return item;                                                                                  
    } catch (Exception exception){                                                                    
        System.out.println(exception);                                                                
        return null;                                                                                  
    }                                                                                                 
}).subscribe(item -> System.out.println("got element :" + item));                                                                                                                                               
```

I have found this old [issue](https://github.com/reactor/reactor-core/issues/572) before the introduction of `onErrorContinue` opperator where someone was complaining about having to wrap his callbacks in a try catch to solve the issue as I have shown in the example.

So I am wondering if there is a reason to prefer `onErrorContinue` over the second approach other than sticking to the functional reactive programming style, maybe? And if there is something wrong with the try-catch approach?

items.body:
I was exploring reactive streams with project reactor, and I had a use case where I needed to skip to the next event if an error occurred during the processing of the current event (e.g., deserialization error).

For such a use case, I found out that I can use the onErrorContinue operator, but I also thought about wrapping my callback with a try catch like this:

        if (item.equals(3)) throw new IllegalArgumentException(); // deserialization issue for example
        return item;                                                                                  
    } catch (Exception exception){                                                                    
        System.out.println(exception);                                                                
        return null;

}).subscribe(item -> System.out.println("got element :" + item));

I have found this old issue before the introduction of onErrorContinue opperator where someone was complaining about having to wrap his callbacks in a try catch to solve the issue as I have shown in the example.

So I am wondering if there is a reason to prefer onErrorContinue over the second approach other than sticking to the functional reactive programming style, maybe? And if there is something wrong with the try-catch approach?

answers.title: How to insert a new node(as prelast) on the list (Linked List)
answers.body:
The idea is that you remove the last item from the list, and keep a reference to it, and then insert the given argument at the end, to finally add the saved node back to the end.

Something like this:

public void insertPreLast(Object obj) throws ListTooSmallException {
    if (isEmpty()) {
        throw ListTooSmallException("List cannot be empty when calling insertPreLast");
    }
    Object saved = removeLast();
    insertLast(obj);
    insertLast(saved);
}

items.body:
I am trying to use CountDownLatch, so that the fourth and fifth threads starts running only after the start of first three threads and these threads add messages into the result list while they are running so that the resultlist and the checklist are equal. I am trying achive this by not using sleep() method.

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.Arrays;
import java.util.List;
import java.util.concurrent.CountDownLatch;

public class ThreadExample {
    private static List<String> resultList = new ArrayList<>();
    private static List<String> checklist = Arrays.asList(
            "threadName1", "threadName2", "threadName3",
            "updateThread", "threadName4",
            "message1", "message2", "message3", "finishThread", "message4"
    );

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        int numberOfThreads = 3;
        CountDownLatch latch = new CountDownLatch(numberOfThreads);

        // Create and start first 3 threads using createThread method
        createThread("threadName1", "message1", latch);
        createThread("threadName2", "message2", latch);
        createThread("threadName3", "message3", latch);

        try {
            // Wait for the first 3 threads to finish
            latch.await();
        } catch (InterruptedException e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }

        createUpdateThread("updateThread", "finishThread");

        createThread("threadName4", "message4", latch);

        // Wait for all threads to finish
        try {
            latch.await();
        } catch (InterruptedException e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }

        // Compare resultList with checklist
        System.out.println("Result List: " + resultList);
        System.out.println("Checklist: " + checklist);
        System.out.println("Lists are equal: " + resultList.equals(checklist));
    }

    private static void createThread(String threadName, String message, CountDownLatch latch) {
        Thread thread = new Thread(() -> {
            resultList.add(threadName);
            latch.countDown(); // Decrease the latch count
            // some functional code
            resultList.add(message);
        });

        // Start the thread
        thread.start();
    }

    private static void createUpdateThread(String updateThread, String finishThread) {
        Thread thread = new Thread(() -> {
            
            resultList.add(updateThread);
            //some functional code
            resultList.add(finishThread);
        });

        // Start the thread
        thread.start();
    }
}

But the result is not same as the threads are running in random order. What can be inserted in the code so that my resultlist will be same as checklist.

answers.title: Get name of the month in Java
answers.body:
Use DateFormatSymbols

Proudly copied and pasted from bluebones.net:

import java.text.*;

String getMonthForInt(int m) {
    String month = "invalid";
    DateFormatSymbols dfs = new DateFormatSymbols();
    String[] months = dfs.getMonths();
    if (m >= 0 && m <= 11 ) {
        month = months[m];
    }
    return month;
}

answers.title: Get name of the month in Java
answers.body:
The Calendar class is not the best class to use when it comes obtaining the localized month name in one statement.

The following is an example of obtaining the month name of a desired month specified by a int value (where January is 1), using only the Calendar class:

// Month as a number.
int month = 1;

// Sets the Calendar instance to the desired month.
// The "-1" takes into account that Calendar counts months
// beginning from 0.
Calendar c = Calendar.getInstance();
c.set(Calendar.MONTH, month - 1);

// This is to avoid the problem of having a day that is greater than the maximum of the
// month you set. c.getInstance() copies the whole current dateTime from system 
// including day, if you execute this on the 30th of any month and set the Month to 1 
// (February) getDisplayName will get you March as it automatically jumps to the next              
// Month
c.set(Calendar.DAY_OF_MONTH, 1);    

// Returns a String of the month name in the current locale.
c.getDisplayName(Calendar.MONTH, Calendar.LONG, Locale.getDefault());

The above code will return the month name in the system locale.

If another locale is required, one can specify another Locale by replacing the Locale.getDefault() with a specific locale such as Locale.US.

answers.body_markdown:
# tl;dr

    Month.of( 12 ).getDisplayName( TextStyle.FULL , Locale.US )

…or…

    Month.DECEMBER.getDisplayName( TextStyle.FULL , Locale.US )

>December

# Using java.time

The modern way to get the localized name of a month is with the [`java.time.Month`][1] enum. This class is part of the java.time package than now supplants the troublesome old legacy date-time classes such as `Date` and `Calendar`. 

To localize, specify:

 - [`TextStyle`](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/time/format/TextStyle.html) to determine how long or abbreviated should the string be.
 - [`Locale`](http://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/Locale.html) to determine (a) the human language for translation of name of day, name of month, and such, and (b) the cultural norms deciding issues of abbreviation, capitalization, punctuation, separators, and such.

Example code.

    Month month = Month.of( 7 );
    String outputConstantName = month.toString();
    String outputMonthNameEnglish = month.getDisplayName( TextStyle.FULL , Locale.US );
    String outputMonthQuébec = month.getDisplayName( TextStyle.FULL , Locale.CANADA_FRENCH );

>month.toString(): JULY

>outputMonthNameEnglish: July

>outputMonthQuébec: juillet

Using the `Month` enum objects by name rather than month number can be handy, easier to read, and less error-prone.

    String output = Month.JULY.getDisplayName( TextStyle.FULL , Locale.US ) ;

----------

# About java.time

The [java.time](http://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/time/package-summary.html) framework is built into Java 8 and later. These classes supplant the troublesome old [legacy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legacy_system) date-time classes such as [`java.util.Date`](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/Date.html), [`Calendar`](https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/util/Calendar.html), & [`SimpleDateFormat`](http://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/text/SimpleDateFormat.html).

The [Joda-Time](http://www.joda.org/joda-time/) project, now in [maintenance mode](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maintenance_mode), advises migration to the [java.time](http://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/time/package-summary.html) classes.

To learn more, see the [Oracle Tutorial](http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/datetime/TOC.html). And search Stack Overflow for many examples and explanations. Specification is [JSR 310](https://jcp.org/en/jsr/detail?id=310).

Where to obtain the java.time classes? 

 - [**Java SE 8**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_version_history#Java_SE_8) and [**SE 9**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_version_history#Java_SE_9) and later
  - Built-in. 
  - Part of the standard Java API with a bundled implementation.
  - Java 9 adds some minor features and fixes.
 - [**Java SE 6**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_version_history#Java_SE_6) and [**SE 7**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Java_version_history#Java_SE_7)
  - Much of the java.time functionality is back-ported to Java 6 & 7 in [***ThreeTen-Backport***](http://www.threeten.org/threetenbp/).
 - [**Android**](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Android_(operating_system))
  - The [***ThreeTenABP***](https://github.com/JakeWharton/ThreeTenABP) project adapts *ThreeTen-Backport* (mentioned above) for Android specifically.
  - See [*How to use ThreeTenABP…*](https://stackoverflow.com/q/38922754/642706).

The [ThreeTen-Extra](http://www.threeten.org/threeten-extra/) project extends java.time with additional classes. This project is a proving ground for possible future additions to java.time. You may find some useful classes here such as [`Interval`](http://www.threeten.org/threeten-extra/apidocs/org/threeten/extra/Interval.html), [`YearWeek`](http://www.threeten.org/threeten-extra/apidocs/org/threeten/extra/YearWeek.html), [`YearQuarter`](http://www.threeten.org/threeten-extra/apidocs/org/threeten/extra/YearQuarter.html), and [more](http://www.threeten.org/threeten-extra/apidocs/index.html).


  [1]: https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/21/docs/api//java.base/java/time/Month.html

answers.title: Tic Tac Toe game beginner level
answers.body:
You're telling the code to exit the loop when the input is invalid:

if (playerSymbol != 'X' && playerSymbol != 'O') {
    System.out.println("Invalid input");
    break;
}

If you want to skip the rest of the loop body and re-iterate the loop, the keyword you're looking for is continue:

if (playerSymbol != 'X' && playerSymbol != 'O') {
    System.out.println("Invalid input");
    continue;
}

answers.title: Exception not throwed to global api error handler
answers.body:
Starting from Spring Security version 6.0, the framework began filtering all dispatcher types, such as request, async, error, forward, and include.

If you want to exclude the error dispatcher type in your scenario, you can configure the filter chain as shown below:

public SecurityFilterChain customFilterChain(HttpSecurity httpSecurity) throws Exception {
    httpSecurity
            .authorizeHttpRequests(auth -> auth
                    .dispatcherTypeMatchers(DispatcherType.ERROR).permitAll()
                    .anyRequest().authenticated()
            )
            .addFilterBefore(new ApiKeyAuthenticationFilter(), UsernamePasswordAuthenticationFilter.class);
    return httpSecurity.build();
}

For additional information on this topic, refer to the Spring Security documentation at this link: https://docs.spring.io/spring-security/reference/5.8/migration/servlet/authorization.html#switch-filter-all-dispatcher-types.

I write global api error handler class

@ControllerAdvice
@Order(Ordered.HIGHEST_PRECEDENCE)
public class ApiGlobalErrorHandler {

    private static final Logger LOG = LoggerFactory.getLogger(ApiGlobalErrorHandler.class.getName());

    @ExceptionHandler(UnauthorizedAccessException.class)
    @ResponseStatus(value = HttpStatus.UNAUTHORIZED)

    protected ApiResponseWrapper handleUnauthorizedAccessException(UnauthorizedAccessException ex) {

items.title: Dynamically create appenders in logback.xml
items.body:
I want to separate each package's logs in their own file without having to create multiple appenders for each file as the appenders will look exactly the same except the file name.

The idea would be to create a logger for each package and set a custom property in each logger to use as an argument in the appender. Something like this:

<configuration>
    <appender name="logFile" class="ch.qos.logback.core.FileAppender">
        <file>${arg1}</file>
        <append>true</append>
        <encoder>
            <pattern>%d{HH:mm:ss} %logger{100} - %msg%n</pattern>
        </encoder>
    </appender>

    <logger name="com.example.myPackage1" level="INFO">
        <appender-ref ref="logFile" arg1="package1.log"/>
    </logger>
    <logger name="com.example.myPackage2" level="INFO">
        <appender-ref ref="logFile" arg1="package2.log"/>
    </logger>
</configuration>

But this configuration just makes me a file named arg1_IS_UNDEFINED instead of the package1.log and package2.log that I intended, which I assume is because the appender does not recognize this arg1 that I just made up.

I also tried to set this arg1 with the <property> tag inside of each logger but I got the same result

Is there any way to do what I want perhaps with a different syntax?

comments.body_markdown: You can use [`GraphicsEnvironment.registerFont`](https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/17/docs/api/java.desktop/java/awt/GraphicsEnvironment.html#registerFont(java.awt.Font)) to make any font loaded via `Font.createFont` available to your UI. So as long as you load it (however you want) before the PlaF tries to use it, that should be sufficient.
